image.altText: Two men in suits, behind podiums, with Israel and US flags in the background, speak at a press conference

items.synopsis: Displaced civilians in Gaza say after mosques and schools were hit by Israeli air strikes, they have nowhere to find safety, while Israel recruits advocates for the country online.

title.children: 'Hamas should be crushed': Netanyahu wants sanctions against any nation who meets with terror group

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Israeli army said it was preparing for a ground assault on Hamas militants in the Gaza Strip but that the country's political leaders had not yet taken a decision. "We are waiting to see what our political leadership decides about a potential ground" incursion, army spokesman Richard Hecht told journalists. "This has not been decided yet... But we are preparing for a ground manoeuvre if it is decided. "We are preparing ourselves for the next stages of war... to prepare for multiple operative contingency plans." He said the possible operation "could be from the air, it could be combined from the sea (and) air". Israel's assault is targeting senior leaders of Hamas, Mr Hecht said, including the group's chief in Gaza, Yahya Sinwar. "Right now we are focused on taking out their senior leadership, not only the military leadership (but) also their governmental leadership, all the way up to Sinwar," Mr Hecht said. "They were directly connected" to the weekend attack, he added. AFP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli army preparing for ground assault

children.content: The Israeli army said it was preparing for a ground assault on Hamas militants in the Gaza Strip but that the country's political leaders had not yet taken a decision.
"We are waiting to see what our political leadership decides about a potential ground" incursion, army spokesman Richard Hecht told journalists.
"This has not been decided yet... But we are preparing for a ground manoeuvre if it is decided.
"We are preparing ourselves for the next stages of war... to prepare for multiple operative contingency plans."
He said the possible operation "could be from the air, it could be combined from the sea (and) air".
Israel's assault is targeting senior leaders of Hamas, Mr Hecht said, including the group's chief in Gaza, Yahya Sinwar.
"Right now we are focused on taking out their senior leadership, not only the military leadership (but) also their governmental leadership, all the way up to Sinwar," Mr Hecht said.
"They were directly connected" to the weekend attack, he added.
AFP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Egypt has denied officially closing the Rafah crossing — the main exit point from besieged Gaza — saying Israeli airstrikes hampered its activities. It has also called on Israel to avoid targeting the Palestinian side of the crossing, saying "repeated bombing" has prevented it from operating normally. For context, two days ago the Israeli military issued a statement which said the gateway between Egypt and Gaza was closed, shortly after suggesting that Palestinian civilians should escape through the crossing. The only other roads out of Gaza are controlled by Israel. In a statement released this evening, Egypt's Foreign Ministry called on all countries and international organizations wishing to provide humanitarian aid to deliver supplies to el-Arish International Airport, in Egypt’s northern Sinai. ABC with reporting from AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Egypt says Israeli air strikes stopped border crossing with Gaza operating

children.content: Egypt has denied officially closing the Rafah crossing — the main exit point from besieged Gaza — saying Israeli airstrikes hampered its activities.
It has also called on Israel to avoid targeting the Palestinian side of the crossing, saying "repeated bombing" has prevented it from operating normally.

For context, two days ago the Israeli military issued a statement which said the gateway between Egypt and Gaza was closed, shortly after suggesting that Palestinian civilians should escape through the crossing.
The only other roads out of Gaza are controlled by Israel.
Egypt, which shares a border with the south of Gaza, says the border crossing remains open.
(Map: ABC News/Leonie Thorne)

In a statement released this evening, Egypt's Foreign Ministry called on all countries and international organizations wishing to provide humanitarian aid to deliver supplies to el-Arish International Airport, in Egypt’s northern Sinai.
ABC with reporting from AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: He tells the press conference anyone who wants peace must condem Hamas's reign of terror. "We know Hamas doesn't represent the Palestinian people or their legitimate aspirations to live with equal measures of security, freedom, justice, opportunity, and dignity," Mr Blinken says. "We know Hamas — instead of promoting the wellbeing of its citizens — rules repressively, and dedicates the resources it has to terror tunnels and rockets. "We know Hamas didn't commit its heinous acts with the interests of Palestinian people in mind. "We know Hamas does not stand for the future that Palestinians want for themselves and for their children. "Hamas has onlyone agenda — to destroy Israel, and to murder Jews. No country can or would tolerate the slaughter of its citizens — or simply return to the conditions that allowed it to take place."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hamas does not represent Palestinian people: Blinken

children.content: He tells the press conference anyone who wants peace must condem Hamas's reign of terror.
"We know Hamas doesn't represent the Palestinian people or their legitimate aspirations to live with equal measures of security, freedom, justice, opportunity, and dignity," Mr Blinken says.
"We know Hamas — instead of promoting the wellbeing of its citizens — rules repressively, and dedicates the resources it has to terror tunnels and rockets.
"We know Hamas didn't commit its heinous acts with the interests of Palestinian people in mind.
"We know Hamas does not stand for the future that Palestinians want for themselves and for their children.
"Hamas has onlyone agenda — to destroy Israel, and to murder Jews.
No country can or would tolerate the slaughter of its citizens — or simply return to the conditions that allowed it to take place."

image.altText: Black letters that spell out PwC on a white wall with red, orange and yellow graphic squares above the letter C.

items.synopsis: Consulting giant PwC is accused of misleading the Senate after revelations it planned to sell its consultancy business at the same time it pushed back against the idea in evidence to a separate inquiry in 2019.

title.children: PwC caught out after telling Senate it was against 'separating' its businesses while looking for a seller in private

image.altText: A wide shot of the front entrance to Casuarina Prison, with two men dressed in blue walking out and trees in the foreground.

items.synopsis: An investigation is underway after a 16-year-old boy was found unresponsive in his cell in juvenile detention at Casuarina Prison in Perth overnight.

title.children: Boy found unresponsive, in critical condition after 'serious incident' in youth wing of adult jail

image.altText: deconstructed bathroom

items.synopsis: Major Perth builder BGC is pleading with homeowners affected by bursting pipes not to start legal action as the company grapples with almost seven burst pipe reports a day.

title.children: Builder and manufacturer trade blows as pipes burst in newly built homes across Perth

image.altText: A man in a hat and Yes t-shirt holds a young child with a Yes campaign flag in the background

items.synopsis: Two days out from the Voice referendum, Noel Pearson is urging voters to think of future generations as they head to the polling booths.

title.children: 'The politicians have vandalised this': Voice co-architect issues last pitch before referendum

image.altText: A young girl wipes a tear while she cries, with an adult standing by her

items.synopsis: While condemning the "horrific crimes committed by Hamas", a group of independent United Nations experts says Israel is resorting to "indiscriminate military attacks against the already exhausted Palestinian people of Gaza".

title.children: UN experts say Israel's strikes on Gaza amount to 'collective punishment'

image.altText: Jim Everett

items.synopsis: Aboriginal activist Jimmy Everett-Puralia Meenamatta doesn't believe the Voice would result in meaningful change for First Nations people. Instead, he'd prefer to see a treaty.

title.children: Why I'd prefer treaty instead of the Voice to Parliament

image.altText: Two female netball players jump for the ball under the net, with another player to the side

items.synopsis: The Diamonds shrug off a week dominated by the Super Netball pay dispute to beat New Zealand by 10 points.

title.children: Diamonds open Constellation Cup series with win over Silver Ferns

image.altText: Three Hezbolah flags fluttering above a poster depicting Lebanon's Hezbollah leader Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah

items.synopsis: Here's what you need to know about Hezbollah and its role in the Israel-Hamas conflict.

title.children: What is Hezbollah and what happens if it gets involved in the Israel-Hamas conflict?

image.altText: A decapitated head of a bronze statue sitting on a desk.

items.synopsis: Police have charged a 38-year-old man in connection with the vandalism, after the statue's head was cut off overnight.

title.children: Man charged over decapitation of bronze statue of Goldfields pioneer Paddy Hannan

image.altText: Cal Wilson wearing a green shirt, and with pink hair and glasses, holds up a microphone while smiling.

items.synopsis: The cause of comedian Cal Wilson's death at age 53 is revealed as a rare form of cancer, as fellow comedians pay tribute to her as "a beacon of warmth and silliness".

title.children: Illness that caused comedian Cal Wilson's death at 53 revealed to be rare form of cancer

image.altText: The mangled metal and glass wreckage of a roof hangs over a building after it collapsed.

items.synopsis: Two companies are charged by Worksafe over the death of construction worker Jonathan Hartshorn, who fell 20 metres when a glass roof gave way at Curtin University three years ago.

title.children: Companies facing millions in fines over death of worker in Curtin University roof collapse

image.altText: Male cricketer wearing yellow, yells and clinches his fists in celebration

items.synopsis: The Australians need a win against South Africa in Lucknow to keep in touch with the top four at the Cricket World Cup. Check out the live scores and stats in our ScoreCentre.

title.children: World Cup live: Australia chasing 312 for victory in World Cup clash against South Africa

image.altText: A huge plume of toxic smoke rises into the clear sky above an outback road.

items.synopsis: Authorities say the disastrous 2020 Beirut blast influenced their decision to wait several days before investigating the site of this week's fatal collision.

title.children: Fire crews access site of deadly Pilbara chemical truck crash as 'massive explosion' risk subsides

image.altText: Bright yellow orange sky with Uluru in foreground.

items.synopsis: The two New South Wales men, who claim to be sovereign citizens, were fined almost $9,000 each for entering and vandalising the prohibited site.

title.children: 'No shame': Pair found guilty of using oily handprints to damage sacred Uluru cave art

image.altText: A man with long hair and a beard carrying a plastic bag

items.synopsis: Police charge a 23-year-old man with intimidation after four teens were allegedly threatened for displaying an Israeli flag across their car in Sydney's eastern suburbs.

title.children: Minister calls man's alleged threat to teens who were displaying Israeli flag 'anti-Semitic'

image.altText: A composite image of Leeser and Cox in profile, smiling as they talk.

items.synopsis: With just days remaining until the Voice referendum, some prominent Yes advocates are contemplating what a No vote could mean for Indigenous policy.

title.children: While Yes supporters remain hopeful, some contemplate what a No vote might mean

image.altText: A composite image of a woman wearing a mustard yellow jumper

items.synopsis: A 17-year-old boy is ordered to stay in juvenile detention after being charged over an alleged hit-and-run that killed 48-year-old Rebecca Collard in Perth's north.

title.children: Teenager charged with murder of woman in alleged Perth hit-and-run held in juvenile detention

image.altText: The back of three ambulances, and the bonnet of a fourth, parked outside a hospital.

items.synopsis: St John Ambulance WA is investigating the death of a man who died from a bee sting in Australind and whether extra resources in the regional community could have saved him.

image.altText: Boys with spears walk the streets of the Bidyadanga Aboriginal community in the West Kimberley.

items.synopsis: Not many know that Western Australia has its own type of voice to government, but the jury is out on whether it has been a "toothless tiger" or a "powerful tool".

title.children: WA's had its own version of the Voice for more than 50 years. How well has it worked?

image.altText: Martin Sibosado

items.synopsis: Just 48 hours out from the Voice to Parliament referendum, leaders across WA's far north say communities need a greater say in how services are delivered and decisions are made.

title.children: In Western Australia's far north, community leaders say the status quo cannot be allowed to continue

image.altText: premier gesturing as she speaks, behind a lecturn

items.synopsis: Those who display, distribute or publish a banned symbol — and cause others to feel harassed or offended — could face up to six months' jail.

title.children: Nazi flags to be banned under new Queensland hate symbol laws. Here's what's changing

image.altText: Vanessa Amorosi getting into a car

image.altText: A man wearing a red singlet and dark-coloured cap.

image.altText: two firefighters looking at burnt ground

items.synopsis: Residents in five regions, including Greater Sydney, are being told to stay alert ahead of the hot and windy conditions forecast for today. The fire risk is rated as high for much of the rest of the state.

title.children: Schools closed, extreme fire danger warnings issued across NSW as South Coast blaze burns on

image.altText: Lidia Thorpe at a press conference.

items.synopsis: Just hours after saying on national radio that she will support a legislated Voice to Parliament if Saturday's referendum fails, Lidia Thorpe walks back her comments and clarifies she will not back the government's model for a Voice.

title.children: Lidia Thorpe backtracks hours after saying she would support a legislated Voice if referendum fails

image.altText: Two panda cubs, sitting in a basket, in front of a sign with their names.

items.synopsis: South Koreans get their first close look at a new pair of baby giant pandas at a name-revealing ceremony.

title.children: 'Cuter in real life': South Korea names its twin pandas 97 days after their birth
